title: Healthy Minds@WORK
dailyReminderText: It's Your Healthy Minds@WORK Well-being Reminder!

tasks.label: audio
tasks.title: Train the Mind, Rewire the Brain

message: You just finished your first HM@WORK meditation. See if you can continue practicing throughout your day.
You can try active practices like the one you just did with any simple activity during your daily life.
Give it a try!
You can practice mindfulness anywhere, and anytime. Try taking a mindful breath or two the next time you’re waiting in line or walking somewhere.
Just two more practices in this series. You’re on a roll. Keep up the good work!

practiceOptions.title: Mindfulness of Breathing
practiceOptions.description: This practice includes three simple steps and provides a good introduction to the different ways of using the breath to cultivate mindful awareness

practiceOptions.title: Relaxing with the Breath
practiceOptions.description: This practice uses the movements of the breath to bring about a state of relaxed, mindful presence.

practiceOptions.title: Unguided Practice
practiceOptions.description: Already a pro? This one doesn’t have any guidance, so you can do a mindfulness of breathing practice at your own pace.

message: Practicing mindfulness for short moments throughout the day creates new connections in the brain.

practiceOptions.title: Mindfulness of Breathing
practiceOptions.description: This practice includes three simple steps and provides a good introduction to the different ways of using the breath to cultivate mindful awareness

practiceOptions.title: Relaxing with the Breath
practiceOptions.description: This practice uses the movements of the breath to bring about a state of relaxed, mindful presence.

practiceOptions.title: Unguided Practice
practiceOptions.description: Already a pro? This one doesn’t have any guidance, so you can do a mindfulness of breathing practice at your own pace.

message: Reflect on the benefits you feel just after training the mind in meditation.
What would life be like with a mind that is more calm and focused?
You finished all the practices in this series. You're on a roll!

message: Remember, the point isn’t to feel a particular way but simply to be aware of how you feel now.

practiceOptions.title: Mindfulness of Breathing
practiceOptions.description: This practice includes three simple steps and provides a good introduction to the different ways of using the breath to cultivate mindful awareness

practiceOptions.title: Feeling the Breath
practiceOptions.description: This practice focuses on the sensations of the breath and is a powerful technique to strengthen mindfulness.

practiceOptions.title: Relaxing with the Breath
practiceOptions.description: This practice uses the movements of the breath to bring about a state of relaxed, mindful presence.

practiceOptions.title: Unguided Practice
practiceOptions.description: Already a pro? This one doesn’t have any guidance, so you can do a mindfulness of breathing practice at your own pace.

message: The more you practice, the easier it gets.
Try practicing while doing something simple today, like brushing your teeth.
Who will you see next? Take a moment to set a clear intention to give them your full attention.

message: What happens when you listen mindfully when another person is talking to you?
Give it a try with the next person you talk to.

message: When you set an intention, focus on the step you’re going to take, not the result.
Don’t worry if you forget to practice during the day.
Stay with the intention, and a habit will eventually take root.

You’re diligent effort is rewiring your brain for the better.

message: Don’t forget, we’re not trying to fix or improve anything here.
We’re simply noticing the qualities of well-being that we already have.

practiceOptions.title: Counting the Breath
practiceOptions.description: This practice is great when the mind is really busy. It involves counting the cycles of breathing to calm the mind.

message: Mindfulness helps us manage emotional reactions, not by controlling them, but by relating to them with openness and curiosity.
See if you can practice mindfulness in whatever comes next in your day.

message: What are you going to be doing today when you’re done with the app?
Why not use it as an opportunity to practice?
Guided practices help you learn the skills, but there’s no point if you don’t apply them in daily life.
Find moments to bring the practice into your day.

All of these practices are strengthening networks in your brain.
You’re doing great!

message: Meditators respond to pain differently than non-meditators, and report less suffering when exposed to physical pain.
Stress speeds up the aging process, but training in mindfulness can reduce the negative impact of stress.

Keep it up. You’re doing great!

message: What are you doing next? Why not use the activity as an opportunity to practice directing your attention on purpose?

practiceOptions.title: A Tour of the Senses
practiceOptions.description: Anything we experience can help us to strengthen our ability to be mindful and attentive. This practice helps us to transform what we see, hear, and feel from sources of distraction into supports for mindful awareness.

practiceOptions.title: Mindfulness of Sound
practiceOptions.description: Sounds have a natural soothing effect on the mind. This practice uses the natural sounds in your environment as a support for mindfulness and attention.

practiceOptions.title: Unguided Practice
practiceOptions.description: Already a pro? This one doesn’t have any guidance, so you can do a mindfulness of breathing practice at your own pace.

message: Remember the four skills involved in paying attention: directing attention, sustaining attention, noticing distractions, and relaxing attention.
Short moments of directing attention on purpose strengthen networks in the brain that help us to manage impulses and emotions.

message: Every time you notice your mind has wandered and bring it back, you’re strengthening circuitry related to "cognitive control".
Are there certain parts of your day where you tend to go on "auto-pilot” and lose touch with the present moment?

message: With external forces trying to pull your mind in different directions, it’s up to you to learn how to focus on the things you want to focus on.
Notice what happens to your attention in different social situations while you’re interacting with other people.

What helps you to stay connected in these moments?

message: Distractions are inevitable.
By strengthening a brain circuit called the “monitoring function”, we can get better at noticing when the mind wanders.
Distractions are not an enemy. Go with the flow of experience.
Anything can be used as a support for mindfulness and attention.
Ready to uni-task?
Pick a short, simple activity and try to do it while sustaining a gentle focused attention from start to finish.

practiceOptions.description: Open awareness is a state of effortless presence. This practice explores different dimensions of this experience and strengthens the ability to relax attentional focus.

message: When might be the right time in your daily routine to intentionally shift from “doing” to “being”?
A relaxed mind is a mind that not trying to control anything, not trying to fix anything, and not trying to improve whatever is happening in the moment.
How have the mindfulness and attention skills you’ve learned in this program so far influenced your daily life?
How might you apply them?

practiceOptions.description: Anything we experience can help us to strengthen our ability to be mindful and attentive. This practice helps us to transform what we see, hear, and feel from sources of distraction into supports for mindful awareness.

practiceOptions.title: Unguided Practice
practiceOptions.description: Already a pro? This one doesn’t have any guidance, so you can do a mindfulness of breathing practice at your own pace.

message: We tend treat distractions as failures.
Instead, try to celebrate the moment when you successfully notice a distracted mind as a victory.

practiceOptions.title: Open Awareness
practiceOptions.description: Open awareness is a state of effortless presence. This practice explores different dimensions of this experience and strengthens the ability to relax attentional focus.

practiceOptions.title: Mindfulness of Seeing
practiceOptions.description: In this practice we use the visual sense to strengthen mindful awareness and the ability to direct and sustain attention.

practiceOptions.title: Mindfulness of Sensations
practiceOptions.description: This practice focuses on the sensations in the body and uses this dimension of experience to calm the mind and manage aspects of attention.

message: Training the mind helps us recover more easily, so we don’t get stuck in emotional reactions or unhelpful thoughts.

message: It’s common to resist thoughts during meditation.
Instead, try to open up to them and get curious and watch as they come and go.

practiceOptions.title: Stepping Out of the River
practiceOptions.description: This practice uses three simple steps to bring awareness to thoughts, memories and impressions in the mind.

practiceOptions.title: Thoughts, Emotions and the Breath
practiceOptions.description: This practice uses the breath as an anchor for awareness as we bring mindful awareness to thoughts and feelings.

practiceOptions.title: Unguided Practice
practiceOptions.description: Already a pro? This one doesn’t have any guidance, so you can do a mindfulness of breathing practice at your own pace.

message: Don’t try to change the clouds.
Just remember that the open sky of awareness is always present, waiting to be noticed.
Take a moment to review the three skills that strengthen self-awareness: Noticing thoughts, noticing emotions, and noticing impulses.
Mindfulness has been shown to calm the “default mode network” in the brain, which is associated with mind-wandering and rumination.

message: Treat any thoughts, mental images or emotions that arise the same way you might treat sounds and sights in the outside world; just notice them.

message: You don’t need to stop the river of thoughts and emotions, but you don’t have to let it sweep you away either.
Explore the “third option”
Mindfulness has been shown to reduce our stress response and improve our recovery as measured by the hormone “cortisol”.
A study showed 2 weeks of meditation training reduced mind-wandering while improving reading comprehension and working memory.

message: Meditation can improve our self-awareness, allowing us to regulate our emotions and manage our stress.
Bring awareness to the storyline, physical sensations, and feeling tone that make up an emotion to loosen its hold on you.
Paying attention to your thoughts and emotions when the mind is relatively calm strengthens connections in the brain that help us to self-regulate.

message: Being aware of the feelings in the body and the thoughts that play out in the mind can completely transform how we experience an emotion.
“Decentering” is the term scientists use to describe the skill of noticing thoughts and reactions as they occur, without getting swept away by them.
The key to self-awareness is taking the time to check on your state of mind.
See if you can do this for short moments throughout your day.
